executive_summary: Nonresidential property managers have seen relatively steady revenue growth in recent years despite disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The pandemic negatively affected downstream demand from office buildings as business closures and the increased prevalence of working from home increased office rental vacancy rates. Still, government stimulus kept downstream demand from falling as much as it might have and an accelerated shift to online shopping led to increased demand from warehouses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Had Mixed Effects
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Nonresidential Property Managers industry endured setbacks amid the COVID-19 pandemic, as remote work, temporary business shutdowns, social distancing and an economic recession took their toll on the value of nonresidential real estate. In spite of reduced demand for office space, increased per capita disposable income and lower interest rates allowed the Nonresidential Property Mangers industry to see growth amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Conversely, declining per capita disposable income and increased interest rates are expected to have contributed to falling industry revenue in 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Downstream Uncertainty Had Some Benefits to Property Managers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite encountering difficulties due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the industry was not hurt to the greatest extent possible.

In recent years, elevated interest rates, inflation and wage costs have resulted in high operating costs for non residential property managers. Integrating a higher level of digital technology into their workflow has been a way for property managers to manage costs. While working from home has stuck around, some companies have pushed a return to office that has benefited nonresidential property managers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Macroeconomic Growth Is Set To Aid Property Managers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The nonresidential property management industry is set to see revenue growth along with overall macroeconomic growth in the coming years. Key external drivers, such as the increasing value of private nonresidential construction, are expected to drive demand for industry services. Moreover, generalized economic growth tends to benefit the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technology Trends Will Shift The Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Major industry players have increasingly adopted novel big data and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to increase value-added offerings to clients. While the industry has not historically been technology-driven, data-driven technology has enhanced decision-making, compliance management, operational efficiency and task automation for industry clients. For example, smart technologies can help operators pinpoint recommendations for building upgrades and budgeting improvements to landlords. These technologies are expected to be further developed during the outlook period, driving demand for leading operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Globalization Is Set To Continue To Increase
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Real estate investments have become increasingly globalized in recent years, and so has the Nonresidential Properties Managers industry. Many operators offer complimentary real estate investment advisory services and as clients' capital flows across borders are expected to increase, so are industry players' foreign property management operations. The growth in corporate outsourcing will likely complement this, as increasingly globalized multinational corporations are anticipated to link their international operations to partnerships with individual property managers to achieve efficiencies at scale.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manage nonresidential real estate for property owners. Property management services relate to the overall operation of a property, including maintenance, rent collection, trash removal, security and some renovation activities. Industry operators may also assist in property-related accounting.
key_trends: The COVID-19 pandemic industry had a mixed effect on nonresidential property managers. While stay-at-home orders and work-from-home presented challenges, the industry ultimately saw growth.

The nonresidential property management industry is set to see continued growth in the coming years. The value of private nonresidential real estate is set to grow, expanding the market available to the industry.
Nonresidential Property managers have faced high operating costs in recent years. High interest rates, inflation and wages have increased industry costs.

Property managers are required to obtain licenses, abide by prescribed fiduciary responsibilities and adhere to antifraud prohibitions. Compliance with these prerequisites is the first step toward developing a positive reputation and securing business.
The bulk of revenue for the nonresidential property industry is accounted for by the property management segment. Most revenue for this segment comes from nonresidential building property management.

Property managers in this industry provide services to a number of nonresidential markets. These include commercial properties, offices and professional properties and industrial and manufacturing properties.

Barriers to entry are significant. Legal barriers pertaining directly to managers include licensing procedures and prescribed fiduciary responsibility. Differentiation between services offered is often minimal, so managers focus on providing quality and various services to separate themselves.

Buyer and supplier power is low to moderate. Property owners have the freedom to choose which property management company to hire while management software is essential but widely available. Property owners' needs and demands can vary significantly from one location to another. This results in a need for local expertise and services, leading to a fragmented industry with many small, localized property management companies.
In house property management is the main substitute for industry services. Many property owners have the capacity to manage their properties without outsourcing to operators in this industry.

Profit was hurt due to decreased demand from commercial and entertainment businesses and offices amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Nonresidential property management industry profit has since increased as downstream demand rebounded. Wage costs for the nonresidential property management industry have rose, though they are expected to have been outpaced by revenue growth. Industry operators have hired more skilled laborers to their businesses to improve task automation and efficiency.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment accounts for demand for nonresidential property management from commercial properties. Business closures and social distancing measures drove down demand from many commercial businesses during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. As consumer spending has grown and unemployment has fallen following the pandemic, demand from commercial properties has largely recovered.

This segment accounts for demand for nonresidential property management from offices and professional properties. With the rising popularity of working from home in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, office rental vacancy rates have rose, driving down demand from this segment. As workplaces continue to adjust to a post-pandemic world in the coming years, demand from this segment is expected to remain below pre-pandemic levels.

This segment accounts for demand for nonresidential property management from industrial and manufacturing properties, as well as other miscellaneous properties. While this segment accounts for the smallest share of industry revenue, it is expected to have seen the strongest growth in recent years, in part as the federal government has recently made investments that has translated into high industrial construction spending.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment accounts for demand for property management services, which accounts for the large majority of industry revenue. The bulk of revenue for this segment comes from nonresidential building property management, while a smaller share comes from land and other property management.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Real Estate Agent and Brokerage Services
products_and_services.product_description: Accounted for in this segment, nonresidential property managers sometimes extend real estate services, including appraisal, brokerage and sales. Helping businesses and individuals acquire rental properties puts managers in a prime position to offer continued management services. The state of the nonresidential real estate market, including trends in property prices, supply and demand imbalances and the market's overall health, can significantly affect the need for appraisal and brokerage services.

tier_1_suppliers: Heating & Air Conditioning Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Power Tools & Other General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Storage & Warehouse Leasing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Buyer and supplier power is low to moderate. Property owners have the freedom to choose which property management company to hire while management software is essential but widely available.

Barriers to entry are significant. Legal barriers pertaining directly to managers include licensing procedures and prescribed fiduciary responsibility. Differentiation between services offered is often minimal, so managers focus on providing quality and various services to separate themselves.
In house property management is the main substitute for industry services. Many property owners have the capacity to manage their properties without outsourcing to operators in this industry.

Differentiation between services offered is often minimal, so managers focus on providing quality and various services to separate themselves.
Buyer and supplier power is low to moderate. Property owners have the freedom to choose which property management company to hire while management software is essential but widely available.

Property owners' needs and demands can vary significantly from one location to another. This results in a need for local expertise and services, leading to a fragmented industry with many small, localized property management companies.
In house property management is the main substitute for industry services. Many property owners have the capacity to manage their properties without outsourcing to operators in this industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage costs have rose along with revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In recent years, wage costs for the nonresidential property management industry have rose, though they are expected to have been outpaced by revenue growth.
Industry operators have hired more data-savvy technologists who can apply artificial intelligence and big data techniques to their businesses to improve task automation and efficiency.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Downstream Construction of and Demand for Nonresidential Real Estate
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for nonresidential property management is impacted by fluctuations in downstream nonresidential construction. In recent years, construction spending has been impacted by interest rates and federal funding.
Volatility for the nonresidential property management industry is influenced by changing demand for nonresidential property. For example, demand for office space has been volatile in recent years.

FAQs.question: What factors impact revenue volatility in the nonresidential property management industry?
FAQs.answer: Downstream construction of and demand for nonresidential real estate impact revenue volatility. Fluctuations in nonresidential construction, influenced by interest rates and federal funding, affect demand for property management services. Changing demand for different types of nonresidential properties like office space also contributes to volatility.

FAQs.question: What is the level of regulation in the nonresidential property management industry?
FAQs.answer: The level of regulation is described as low and steady.

FAQs.question: What is the level of industry assistance for the nonresidential property management industry?
FAQs.answer: The level of industry assistance is described as low and steady.
